title: Cornelius and Peter
shortSummary: Acts chapter 10 narrates the divine encounter between Cornelius, a God-fearing Gentile centurion, and Peter, an apostle of Jesus Christ. This chapter marks a pivotal moment in the early church, revealing God's plan to extend salvation beyond the Jews to the Gentiles, emphasizing that God shows no partiality.
timeline: c. AD 30-33 - Early Church Expansion after Christ's Resurrection

keyCharacters.name: Cornelius
keyCharacters.description: A Roman centurion stationed in Caesarea, described as devout and God-fearing, whose vision leads to the first Gentile conversion.

keyCharacters.name: Peter
keyCharacters.description: One of Jesus' apostles who receives a vision from God, teaching him that the Gospel is for all people, both Jews and Gentiles.

keyCharacters.name: Angel of God
keyCharacters.description: A heavenly messenger who appears to Cornelius, instructing him to send for Peter.

definitions.definition: A commander of approximately one hundred soldiers in the Roman army.
In Jewish law, items or persons considered ceremonially impure and forbidden for consumption or association.
The third Person of the Trinity, God’s Spirit who empowers, guides, and sanctifies believers.
Charitable giving to the poor, considered an act of righteousness and devotion.

outline.heading: Cornelius’ Vision and Instructions
outline.description: Cornelius, a devout Gentile centurion, receives a vision from an angel instructing him to send for Peter in Joppa, highlighting God's initiative to bring the Gospel to the Gentiles.

outline.heading: Peter’s Vision and Divine Revelation
outline.description: Peter experiences a vision of a sheet with unclean animals and is commanded by God to eat, symbolizing the removal of Jewish ceremonial barriers and the acceptance of Gentiles.

outline.heading: Peter Meets Cornelius’ Delegation
outline.description: Peter is guided by the Holy Spirit to welcome Cornelius’ men, demonstrating obedience and openness to God’s expanding plan.

outline.heading: Peter’s Visit to Cornelius and His Household
outline.description: Peter arrives in Caesarea, explains his vision, and listens to Cornelius’ testimony, preparing to share the Gospel with Gentiles.

outline.heading: Peter’s Sermon and the Outpouring of the Holy Ghost
outline.description: Peter proclaims that God shows no partiality and preaches Jesus Christ to the Gentiles; the Holy Spirit falls on all who hear, affirming their inclusion in the church and leading to their baptism.

application: Trust God’s leading even when it challenges cultural or traditional boundaries, as Peter did when accepting Gentiles.
Recognize that God honors sincere faith and righteousness regardless of background, encouraging believers to pray and give generously like Cornelius.
Be open to the Holy Spirit’s guidance in sharing the Gospel with all people, embracing God’s inclusive plan for salvation.
Respond in obedience to God’s commands promptly, as Cornelius and Peter both demonstrated.

keyVerses.text: Then Peter opened his mouth, and said, Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of persons:
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the foundational truth that God does not show favoritism, affirming the universal offer of salvation.

keyVerses.text: To him give all the prophets witness, that through his name whosoever believeth in him shall receive remission of sins.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the central gospel message that forgiveness of sins is available to all who believe in Jesus Christ.

keyVerses.text: While Peter yet spake these words, the Holy Ghost fell on all them which heard the word.
keyVerses.significance: This verse confirms the Holy Spirit’s acceptance of Gentile believers, validating their inclusion in the church.

keyVerses.text: And he commanded them to be baptized in the name of the Lord. Then prayed they him to tarry certain days.
keyVerses.significance: It marks the formal initiation of Gentile converts into the Christian community through baptism.
